Display the current session most low and most high temperature reached by the unit.
Display the most low and most high temperature reached by the unit during his entire life time.
Display the temperature limits that device should not trespass when powered on.
Display the environment temperature limits that should not trespassed when device is not powered on.
This device is not in smartctl database
This device is in smartctl database
Device report is no longer available. Please, check file path.
S.M.A.R.T. not available on this device.
No S.M.A.R.T. value have exceeded the threshold.
Some S.M.A.R.T. values have exceeded the threshold! Drive failure excepted in less 24 hours. Save all data!
Detected % bad sectors. Backup all data and replace the disk!
Enable or disable Self-Monitoring, Analysis and Reporting Technology on device
Enable or disable S.M.A.R.T. offline test, which scans the device every four hours for disk defects
Enable or disable S.M.A.R.T. autosave of device vendor-specific attributes
S.M.A.R.T. not fully supported on device %.
Offline data collection enabled on device %.
Offline data collection not supported or\aborted from host on device %.
Disable offline data collection on device %?
Offline data collection disabled on device %.
Unable to disable offline data collection\on device %.

Advanced Acoustic Management (AAM) is a method for reducing acoustic emanations in ATA mass storage devices. A quietest value means a slow disk, a loudest value means a fast disk.\Set value to 0 to disable this feature.\\Note that the AAM feature was declared obsolete in ATA ACS-2 Revision 4a (Dec 2010).

Advanced Power Management (APM) is an API (Application Programming Interface) developed by Intel and Microsoft and released in 1992 which enables an operating system running an IBM-compatible personal computer to work with the BIOS (part of the computer's firmware) to achieve power management. If a value between 1 and 254 is provided, it will attempt to enable APM and set the specified value, setting value to 0 disables APM. Values below 128 are supposed to allow drive spindown, values 128 and above adjust only head-parking frequency.

Sets the standby (spindown) timer and places the drive in the IDLE mode. A value of 0 disables the standby timer. Values from 1 to 240 specify timeouts from 5 seconds to 20 minutes in 5 second increments. Values from 241 to 251 specify timeouts from 30 minutes to 330 minutes in 30 minute increments. Value 252 specifies 21 minutes. Value 253 specifies a vendor specific time between 8 and 12 hours. Value 255 specifies 21 minutes and 15 seconds.

Enabling disk write caching may increase operating system performance. By enabling write caching file system corruption and/or data loss could occur if the machine experiences a power device or system failure and cannot be shutdown properly.\The write cache is usually enabled by default for HDD, but not always for SSD.

Drives are configured with a feature called Read Look Ahead that keeps the drive reading ahead, even after execution of the current command has completed. The data is retained in the drive buffer to provide a prompt response to a system request if the ensuing command is indeed sequential.\Read look-ahead is usually enabled by default for HDD, but not always for SSD.
If is disabled, disk write scheduling is executed on a first-in-first-out (FIFO) basis. If is enabled, the disk write scheduling may be reordered by the drive.
Device does not support error logging.
Error % occurred at disk power-on lifetime
When command that caused the error occurred, the device was
After command completion occurred, register were
Command leading to the command that caused the error were
Decimal seconds since the previous disk power-on.\Note: timestamp 'wraps' after 2^32 msec = 49.710 days.
Measured from power on, and printed as DDd+hh:mm:SS:sss\where DD=days, hh=hours, mm=minutes, SS=sec and sss=millisec.\It 'wraps' after 49.710 days.
Indicates that the requested command has been aborted due to a drive status error (not ready, write fault, etc.) or because the command code is invalid.
Indicates that the data address mark has not been found after finding the correct identification field.
Indicates that the requested command have reached the time limit without his completion.
Indicated that the end of the media has been reached.
Indicates that an interface CRC (Cyclic Redundancy Code) error has occurred during an Ultra DMA (Direct Memory Access) data transfer.
Indicates that the requested sector's identification field could not be found.
Is specific to the SCSI command set implemented by ATAPI devices (i.e.: tapes).
Indicates that the media has been changed. A transition from media not ready to ready.
The door button on a removable media drive has been pressed, indicating the operator's wish to remove the media. This may require some program to issue a media eject command or a door unlock command.
Indicates that no media is present in a removable media device.
Indicates that the requested command were defined in previous ATA standards but have been declared obsolete in the standard of this device.
Indicates that the track 0 has not been found during a recalibrate command.
Indicates that an uncorrectable data error has been encountered.
Indicates that the media in a removable media device is write protected.
Device does not support self-test logging.
Device does not support selective self-test logging.
No selective self-test have been logged.

Self-tests are devices built-in tests designed to recognize device fault conditions; these tests are safe for user data. Tests can be performed during normal device use, but take a more longer time despite the extimated times reported below if device is busy.\Note that some devices can't start to register test results until a non-positive result may occur (in force of an abortion or an error is occurred).

Checks the electrical and mechanical performance as well as the read performance of the disk. Electrical tests might include a test of buffer RAM, a read/write circuitry test, or a test of the read/write head elements. Mechanical test includes seeking and servo on data tracks. Scans small parts of the drive's surface (area is vendor-specific and there is a time limit on the test). Checks the list of pending sectors that may have read errors.
A longer and more thorough version of the short self-test, scans the entire disk surface, with no time limit.
Intended as a quick test to identify damage incurred during transporting of the device. Only available on ATA drives.
Start a S.M.A.R.T. offline test, updating attributes values, and if error are found they will appear into the error log.
Specifies how tolerant smartctl should be of ATA and S.M.A.R.T. command failures.
Smartctl exit on failure of any mandatory S.M.A.R.T. command, and ignore all failures of optional S.M.A.R.T. commands.
Smartctl exit on failure of any optional S.M.A.R.T. command.
Smartctl ignore failures of any number of mandatory S.M.A.R.T. commands.

Set a vendor-specific raw value print format, an optional byte order and an optional name for attribute ID. The attribute ID can be in range 1 to 255. If 'N' is specified as ID, the settings for all attributes are changed.
Raw attribute number '9' is power-on time in minutes.
Raw attribute number '9' is power-on time in seconds.
Raw attribute number '9' is power-on time, measured in units of 30 seconds.
Raw attribute number '9' is the disk temperature in Celsius.
Raw attribute number '192' is the Emergency Retract Cycle Count;\is used by some Fujitsu.
Raw attribute number '193' contains two values: the first is the number of load cycle,\the second is the number of unload cycles.
Raw attribute number '194' is ten time the disk temperature in Celsius\(this is used by some Samsung).
Raw attribute number '194' is NOT the disk temperature, and its interpretation is unknown.
Raw attribute number '197' is the Total Pending Sectors.
Raw attribute number '198' is the Total Offline Uncorrectable.
Raw attribute number '198' is the Offline Scan Uncorrectable Sector Count.
Raw attribute number '200' is the Write Error Count.
Raw attribute number '201' is the Detected Thermal Asperity Count.
Raw attribute number '220' is the disk temperature in Celsius.
raw8:\Print the Raw value as six 8-bit unsigned base-10 integers.
raw16:\Print the Raw value as three 16-bit unsigned base-10 integers.
raw16(avg16):\Raw attribute is spin-up time. It is printed as a 16-bit value and\an optional 'Average' 16-bit value if the word is nonzero.\This is the default for Attribute '3'.
raw16(raw16):\Print the raw attribute as a 16-bit value and two optional 16-bit\values if these words are nonzero.\This is the default for Attributes '5' and '196'.
raw48:\Print the Raw value as a 48-bit unsigned base-10 integer.\This is the default for most attributes.
raw64:\Print the Raw value as a 64-bit unsigned base-10 integer.\This new raw format is used by some recent SSD devices.
hex48:\Print the Raw value as a 12 digit hexadecimal number.
hex64:\Print the Raw value as a 16 digit hexadecimal number.\This new raw format is used by some recent SSD devices.
min2hour:\Raw Attribute is power-on time in minutes.
sec2hour:\Raw Attribute is power-on time in seconds.
halfmin2hour:\Raw Attribute is power-on time, measured in units of 30 seconds.
tempminmax:\Raw Attribute is the disk temperature in Celsius.\This is the default for Attributes '190' and '194'.
temp10x:\Raw Attribute is ten times the disk temperature in Celsius.
Set firmware debug (on most cases this is not required)
Suppresses read attempts of SMART or General Purpose Log Directory
Modifies the behavior of smartctl to compensate for some known and understood device firmware or driver bug.
Assume that the device firmware obeys the ATA specifications.

Enable on Samsung device in case of no self-test log printed, even though you have run self-tests, very large numbers of ATA errors reported in the ATA error log or strange and impossible values for the ATA error log timestamps.

Your Samsung disk needs this option if the self-test log is printed correctly, but there are a very large number of errors in the SMART error log. In example, a disk with five errors (0x0005) will appear to have 20480 errors (0x5000).
Some Samsung disks (at least SP2514N with Firmware VF100-37) report a self-test still in progress with 0% remaining when the test was already completed.
Fixes byte swapped ATA identify strings returned by some buggy device drivers.
Support for all standard logs is assumed without an actual check. Some Intel SSDs may freeze if log address 0 is read.
Fixes LBA byte ordering in Extended Comprehensive SMART error log. Some disk use little endian byte ordering instead of ATA register ordering to specify the LBA addresses in the log entries.

Specifies if smartctl should exit before performing any checks when the device is in a low-power mode. It may be used to prevent a disk from being spun-up by smartctl. The power mode is ignored by default.
Check the device unless it is in sleep mode.
Check the device unless it is in sleep or standby mode. In these modes most disks are not spinning, so if you want to prevent a disk from spinning up, this is probably what you want.
Check the device unless it is in sleep, standby or idle mode. In the idle state, most disks are still spinning, so this is probably not what you want.
Enable Global Logging Target Save Disabled (GLTSD)

Enable or disable the value of the GLTSD in the Control Mode Page. Some disk manufacturers disable this value by default.\This prevents error counters, power-up hours and other useful data from being placed in non-volatile storage, so these values may be reset to zero the next time the device is power-cycled. If enabled, it clear the GLTSD and thus enable saving counters to non-volatile storage. For extreme streaming-video type applications you might consider to disable the GLTSD.
Enable or disable write cache. The write cache is usually enabled by default.
Enable or disable read cache. The read cache is usually enabled by default.
Run background long test. Estimated duration: %1 seconds (%2 minutes).

This is a debug specific for devices attached to an ASMedia 106x SATA controller. You have to check this box only if the currently selected device is connected to this type of controller and his output is incomplete.\\This issue appear (at least) with controller driver version 3.1.6.0.\\Note that this is a per-drive setting.
No event recorded for this device.
No event recorded for selected period.
Display debug events in main window
You need to restart HDD Guardian to make this setting work.
Add a clipboard device for 3ware outputs

Here you can add devices that smartctl or HDD Guardian can't detect. You have to simply write his location and the right type by using smartctl commands.\If you have more than a drive that don't appear, separate each drive command with a comma. If a drive is an USB device, put into the command the note [USB] to tell to HDD Guardian how to threat it.\\In example:\/dev/sdd -d sat\[USB] /dev/sdg -d usbjmicron, /dev/sdh -d scsi
You need to restart HDD Guardian when you change a setting here.
Number of disks attached to controller
